caption: Line was very long. It wrapped completely around the building, but it moved fast. Inside was beautiful, the atmosphere was fantastic and everyone enjoyed tremendously. Buy tickets in advance!

Have been here for Art Basel in Oct 2024, loved this place! It’s warm, bright and comfy inside. Easy to find food (look at price tags lol), a lot of place to seat as well as the inner decorations are majestic
Paris Photo was massive and the best quality photo sure I've been to. Venue was great, impressive in its own right with lots of access to refreshment and toilets.

The ice rink is available from December 14, 2024 to January 8, 2025. We reserved the tickets few weeks in advance.  The wait line is very long but it took us about 30-40 mins to get in.  It was a one of a kind experience to skate on the world's largest indoor ice rink. Definitely a great add on if you travel to Paris during winter.

Art Basel was a little too crowded and leaves you exhausted. But wonderful art 🎨.  Making a line for Dolce Gabbana for 45 min at -1 degrees is not really worth. Hard to book in advance when you are a tourist.

Extremely Disorganized and Unsafe Experience at Grand Palais Skating Rink  Our visit to the Grand Palais skating rink was an absolute disappointment. We booked tickets for the 9 PM timeslot, expecting a smooth and organized experience. However, upon arrival, we were shocked to see over 500 people waiting in line. After standing in line for 45 minutes with almost no progress, we approached a security guard who informed us we would likely have to wait another 90 minutes to enter.  What is the point of assigning timeslots if they are not enforced? This level of disorganization completely defeats the purpose and results in chaos for paying customers.  Additionally, safety is a major concern. Based on what we observed, there were already at least 300 people inside the skating rink. The space was clearly overcrowded, with far too many skaters per square meter. This raises serious questions about the safety of participants, both in terms of skating collisions and the lack of any feasible plan for emergency evacuations. The venue’s capacity seemed dangerously exceeded, putting everyone at risk.  Grand Palais needs to address its booking system, crowd management, and safety standards immediately. This experience was not only frustrating but also concerning on multiple levels. We would not recommend this to anyone until these issues are resolved.

During my recent visit to Paris, I was awestruck by the Grand Palais, particularly its magnificent Nave. As I stood beneath the colossal glass roof, I couldn't help but marvel at the sheer scale of the structure. A tour guide mentioned an intriguing fact that left me amazed - the Nave apparently contains more steel than the iconic Eiffel Tower itself!  The guide explained that this architectural wonder was constructed for the Universal Exhibition of 1900, showcasing the pinnacle of engineering at the turn of the century. As I gazed up at the intricate metalwork supporting the vast expanse of glass, I tried to imagine the immense amount of steel used in its construction.  What truly captivated me was the glass roof itself. Stretching as far as the eye could see, it created a sense of openness and light that was simply breathtaking. I learned that it's considered the largest of its kind in Europe, which only added to my appreciation of this remarkable building.  Standing there, I felt a deep sense of admiration for the visionaries who created this masterpiece. The Grand Palais, to me, perfectly embodies the French spirit of pushing boundaries in both technology and art. It's a testament to human ingenuity and a must-see for anyone visiting Paris who appreciates architectural marvels.

Built in 1900 and still going strong, this glass domed structure clearly catches the eye, as it is a stand out feature. Seen from across the river at the Northern end of Alexander III bridge it proivides a huge photo opportunity.
Great events but the organisation is not at the same level of the location. For some of the events you buy the ticket in advance and you end up queuing not respecting your time slot…
Such a marvellous place! Well restored. Beauty and splendid art in one place. It was a true dream. Plenty of toilets that are clean and spacious.
We were there for the ice-skating. It was fantastic! We had reserved tickets for a specific time, but the line to get in was ENORMOUS! It was well worth the wait, though.
have been visiting the Chiharu Shiota exhibition at the Grand Palais. Compact expo for a sizeable 14€. still worth it if you appreciate modern installations.
Absolutely gorgeous building! Wonderful art exhibits and truly amazing space.

Went to the exposition by Chiharu Shiota. It was a great experience. The piece in the video specially impacted me, as it reminded me of my pretty nomadic life. Really recommend going to see it and get inspired

The worst skiing experience of my life:  1. 1.5 hours waiting in a very long queue at -1°C with strong winds and no shelter. 2. Rude staff. 3. Our water was stolen at the entrance. 4. The ice surface is very small, only 30% of the whole building. 5. No access to the bar from the ice. 6. Everything is dirty; forget about hygienic measurements to get ski shoes. 7. Dirty toilets
A great place to shop in Paris. I do not recommend going in December, is way too busy. The surrounding areas is absolutely amazing, full of restaurants.
Stunning building with glass rooftop. Venue for Fencing competition at Paris Olympics 2024. This place is accessible from inside only during events.
Opened after 5 years of restauration. The expo of Chiharu Shiota is magnificent. Wow effect

left a good impression! The decor was beautiful and vibrant, with music creating a fun and lively atmosphere. It was a unique experience, and we had a good time despite a few hiccups.  The line was long—even with tickets for 10:30, we got on the ice around 12. The rink was quite crowded, which made skating a bit challenging. However, the stunning setting and overall vibe made it worth the wait. Improving the organization could make the experience even better!
Looks marvelous. We did not get the time to visit inside and in more detail. Aesthetic and nice.

Really fun once you're inside, but 36€ is a high price to pay for 2h total of waiting (1h to get in, 30min to get the skates and 30min to return them).  We tried to going later to avoid the line (arrival around 10pm), but in reality there was a long line right up through 1am on Friday night.  The ice was pretty packed through closing.  It was also a pity one couldn't take a break to go to the restroom/get a drink without returning the skates and waiting in line all over again 🤦‍♀️. Once we were actually on the ice, it was fun though very crowded.

My first time setting foot in the Grand Palais for Art Basel Paris and it was gorgeous. The detail in the architecture is spectacular and this was a really cool art exhibit to look out for if you can, bringing together a bunch of different galleries works.

Not worth it. So you arrive and wait 45 minutes in line, the place is super packed that you can barely skate and the ice is not clean because they let way too many people in at once .There should be a limit so one can actually have room to skate and enjoy, otherwise what are the online reservations for ? No music is really played (like really, and it is so low that you hear nothing), and every once in awhile they put a spectacle of lights. Really dissapointed, and I went on a Thursday around 4p.m. smh. Do anything in Paris is starting to become a real disappointment.
Beautiful. Absolutely stunning. The ice skating here was a highlight in Paris

The Grand Palais in Paris is a historic and iconic exhibition hall and museum complex located near the Champs-Élysées and Place de la Concorde.  Built for the 1900 Exposition Universelle (World's Fair), it is renowned for its impressive glass-domed roof, which is a prime example of Beaux-Arts architecture.  The Grand Palais hosts a wide array of events, including art exhibitions, fashion shows, and cultural events. Its grandeur and architectural beauty make it a significant landmark in Paris, attracting visitors from around the world.  The complex also houses the Galeries nationales du Grand Palais, which display major art exhibitions. The building has undergone various restorations to preserve its structural integrity and aesthetic appeal.
Amazing place, full of history, was there for OG  but the scale and the work they did to that place and ongoing renovation is just amazing. It's a must see place to visit.

Ice skating rink: Super expensive (from €25 for a session of max 4 hours) for a small area with suboptimal ice and then they make you go in socks over the cold and watery floor because you need to go to a specific section. I don’t think I will be back. Forgot to mention - overcrowded.

!!DO NOT BOOK THE ICE SKATING AND DO NOT PAY FOR IT ONLINE!! The length of the queue was unbelievable - this is with fully paid pre-reserved tickets as well.   Expect to queue for HOURS past your reserved time slot as the queue winds up to almost reach Franklin Roosevelt metro station. No idea how this tragedy was allowed to be organised, it is robbery
The ice rink from December to January is absolutely worth it. This space is magical and worth seeing any time.

Le palais des glaces was amazing, well worth the wait in line. The light show was great to watch, one of a kind ice skating experience. Come early for the evening session. The line was about 90 minutes to get in, and the management should work on improving it. There is plenty of space to add a second line and checkpoint around the other side of the block.

I had high hopes for ice skating at the Grand Palais, but it turned out to be a nightmare. Despite having a ticket with an assigned time slot, the line was over a mile long, and we were left waiting endlessly. The assigned time slots are clearly meaningless since no one could get inside at their designated time.  The staff seemed overwhelmed and unprepared for the crowd, offering no clear explanations or solutions. By the time we finally entered, we were frustrated, cold, and exhausted, which ruined the experience.
It was closed for renovations during my visit in may. But what we saw from the outside it was beautiful.

Went for the ice skating. More than an hour in the queue even though you're supposed to select a time frame beforehand. Once near the door, you suddenly get told no food allowed inside even though we just came from the Christmas markets and had macaroons to take home. Once finally inside, very pretty skating rink with nice music and lighting.

I went ice skating during the day and it felt like such a scam, the line was huge and even though I had a ticket already and I arrived there half an hour before, I ended up getting inside half an hour later than the time on my ticket. This left only 1 hour of skating, which was in fact 45 minutes. Inside there is no music by day and there were so many people on the rink that you just could not move, it was also quite dangerous because of this. The ice had not been cleaned for many hours, and it was watery in some areas, again very dangerous. All in all, a joke.
Fantastic evening. Shame it took over an hour to get in. However what an experience
Always a pleasure to visit this amazing space. This time for the Christmas ice skating. We ticked the box but the wait in the queue was long.

Literally the worst organized thing I have ever done in 40 years.   Zero stars.   Had tickets for ice skating at a specific time, still waited in line for 2 hrs.  Got to front of line, finally, no skates!   Finally got skates and place closed.   Waited in line for another 1.5 hrs to return skates.   Again zero stars!

I went ice skating at the palace during the 11:00am block. Yes, the line was long but it moved quickly. Once I got in getting my skates was easy. The rink was busy but still room to easily skate around at a fun pace. The ice was fine, not bumpy, smooth enough to easily glide along. All Good Things!
